title: Nelson Mandela memorial: President Obama honors Nelson Mandela
content:
President Barack Obama is the only American set to speak at the memorial on Tuesday . | REUTERS Obama honors Mandela
JOHANNESBURG — President Barack Obama praised Nelson Mandela ’ s unique role in changing his country and the world — and inspiring him to work to become the first black president of the United States — as he eulogized the former South African president at a memorial service Tuesday .
“ To the people of South Africa — people of every race and walk of life — the world thanks you for sharing Nelson Mandela with us . His struggle was your struggle . His triumph was your triumph . Your dignity and hope found expression in his life , and your freedom , your democracy is his cherished legacy , ” Obama said to the roars of a rain-soaked crowd that numbered in the tens of thousands .
Mandela was “ the last great liberator of the 20th century , ” Obama said , comparing him to leaders who came earlier in the century : Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr . He also likened Mandela to Abraham Lincoln , who held “ his country together when it threatened to break apart . ”
Obama traced Mandela ’ s journey from activist to persistent prisoner to the first black president of South Africa to living legend , and implored those listening to take their own action in the leader ’ s memory .
“ With honesty , regardless of our station or circumstance , we must ask : How well have I applied his lessons in my own life ? ” he said .
“ It is a question I ask myself — as a man and as a president . We know that like South Africa , the United States had to overcome centuries of racial subjugation . As was true here , it took the sacrifice of countless people — known and unknown — to see the dawn of a new day . Michelle and I are the beneficiaries of that struggle , ” he said , drawing roars from the crowd and vuvuzela music as he delivered particularly stirring lines .
“ But in America and South Africa , and countries around the globe , we can not allow our progress to cloud the fact that our work is not done , ” he continued . There are more struggles to work through . “ Around the world today , we still see children suffering from hunger , and disease ; run-down schools , and few prospects for the future . Around the world today , men and women are still imprisoned for their political beliefs ; and are still persecuted for what they look like , or how they worship , or who they love . ”
He took slugs at some of those who ’ ve been honoring Mandela in recent days , perhaps thinking of Zimbabwe ’ s Robert Mugabe or Cuba ’ s Raul Castro , with whom he shook hands before taking the lectern Tuesday . Obama also exchanged brief greetings with Afghan President Hamid Karzai .
“ There are too many of us who happily embrace Madiba ’ s legacy of racial reconciliation but passionately resist even modest reforms that would challenge chronic poverty and growing inequality , ” the president said . “ There are too many leaders who claim solidarity with Madiba ’ s struggle for freedom but do not tolerate dissent from their own people . And there are too many of us who stand on the sidelines , comfortable in complacency or cynicism when our voices must be heard . ”
As he did while traveling in South Africa this summer , Obama called on young people to be inspired by Mandela ’ s lead , just as he was three decades ago .
“ We will never see the likes of Nelson Mandela again … let me say to the young people of Africa , and young people around the world — you can make his life ’ s work your own , ” he said .
( TIMELINE : A look at major events in Nelson Mandela ’ s life )
Obama suggested he ’ s tried to do that . Mandela “ stirred something in me ” as an undergraduate at Occidental College , he recalled . As a persistent anti-apartheid activist , Mandela “ woke me up to my responsibilities — to others , and to myself — and set me on an improbable journey that finds me here today , ” he continued . “ And while I will always fall short of Madiba ’ s example , he makes me want to be better . He speaks to what is best inside us . ”
The president was joined by first lady Michelle Obama and by Presidents George W. Bush , Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter , plus former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton at the service , and was the only American to speak .
Bush was booed when he was shown on large video monitors throughout the stadium , local press said .
Obama spoke toward the middle of the service , which started roughly an hour after the scheduled time of 11 a.m. local time — 4 a.m. in Washington — after Mandela ’ s family and friends , and following United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon .
Obama was followed by Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff , Chinese Vice President Li Yuanchao , Namibian President Hifikepunye Pohamba , Indian President Pranab Mukherjee and Cuba ’ s Castro . As they spoke , young people danced through the stadium , often drowning out the remarks from the stage and drawing requests for quiet until the speeches were complete .
The service ended with a shouted keynote speech by South African President Jacob Zuma and a sermon by the general secretary of the World Methodist Council .
A steady rain in Johannesburg further complicated the logistics for dignitaries , worsening traffic jams in the city . Authorities organized a series of free trains and buses to bring mourners to the site . Two overflow stadiums were available if the main venue filled up . Satellite sites to view the memorial service were set up around the country .
Obama landed at an air force base outside Johannesburg several hours before the service was set to begin Tuesday . He is expected to stay in town for a few hours after the service before returning to Washington . The president ’ s delegation also includes top administration officials , such as National Security Adviser Susan Rice , Attorney General Eric Holder and White House senior adviser Valerie Jarrett .
Mandela is set to be laid to rest following a state funeral in his home province of Qunu on Sunday . An official U.S. delegation is also expected to attend that event , but Obama will not , the White House said .
No bilateral meetings were planned by the White House with the slew of foreign leaders in town for Tuesday ’ s memorial service , though Obama was expected to have an informal talk with Zuma , deputy national security adviser Ben Rhodes said .
The president also hopes to be able to meet with the Mandela family — some of whom he saw over the summer while visiting South Africa — but logistics will determine whether the meeting can happen .
